name: Avoid hard-coded credentials
associatedValueName: Call stack from hard-coded string down to the target method
description: This rule will detect a call path where a hard-coded credential is sent to a method used for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components or validate the authentication for retrieval of data.
output:
Lists all methods that call target methods, passing at least one hard-coded credential parameter. 

It provides the following information : 
 - Method full name. 
 - Call stack with bookmarks from hard-coded credential literal down to the target method.
rationale:
The software should not have hard-coded credentials (such as a passwords) in the application code or files. 
Hard-coded credentials typically create a significant security hole that allows an attacker to bypass the authentication that has been configured by the software administrator. 
This hole might be difficult for the system administrator to detect. Even if detected, it can be difficult to fix, so the administrator may be forced into disabling the product entirely.
reference:
CWE-798: Use of hard-coded credentials
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/798.html

CWE-259: Use of Hard-coded Password
https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/259.html

Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP)
https://www.owasp.org/index.php/A3_2004_Broken_Authentication_and_Session_Management
remediation:
Potential remediations: 
- Outbound authentication: consider storing passwords and keys outside of the code, in the most strongly-protected, encrypted storage. This storage should be protected from outsiders, even other local users from the same system. 
- Inbound authentication: consider using login authentication with strong passwords or keys instead of hard-coding passwords. 
- If hard-coded credentials cannot be removed, perform access control checks and limit accessed resources.
remediationSample: // Store passwords outside of the code in a storage protected from outsiders
alternativeName: Ensure you don't have hard-coded credentials in your source code because it could be retro-engineered by attackers.

OWASP-2013-A2 Broken Authentication and Session Management

qualityStandards.name: Hard-Coded Credentials Usage for Remote Authentication
qualityStandards.description:
Objective
Avoid the existence of hard-coded credentials elements

Consequence
Software featuring weak authentication practices incurs the risk of exposing resources and functionality to unintended actors, possibly leading to compromised sensitive information and even the execution of arbitrary code

Measure Element
Number of instances where a storable data element or member data element is initialized by a ‘Write’ action, transported throughout the application along the transport sequence composed of ActionElements with DataRelations relations, some of which being part of named callable and method control elements, and ultimately used in the remote resource management action ; the transport sequence is composed of assignment operations as updates to the value would not be considered as hard-coded (literal) any more.

qualityStandards.name: Broken Authentication and Session Management
qualityStandards.description: Application functions related to authentication and session management are often not implemented correctly, allowing attackers to compromise passwords, keys, or session tokens, or to exploit other implementation flaws to assume other users' identities.

qualityStandards.name: Broken Authentication
qualityStandards.description: Application functions related to authentication and session management are often implemented incorrectly, allowing attackers to compromise passwords, keys, or session tokens, or to exploit other implementation flaws to assume other users' identities temporarily or permanently.

qualityStandards.name: Broken User Authentication
qualityStandards.description: Authentication mechanisms are often implemented incorrectly, allowing attackers to compromise authentication tokens or to exploit implementation flaws to assume other user's identities temporarily or permanently. Compromising system's ability to identify the client/user, compromises API security overall.

qualityStandards.name: The application must not contain embedded authentication data.
qualityStandards.description: Authentication data stored in code could potentially be read and used by anonymous users to gain access to a backend database or application servers. This could lead to compromise of application data.
